Protein Function: The UvrABC repair system catalyzes the recognition androcessing of DNA lesions. UvrC both incises the 5' and 3' sidesf the lesion. The N-terminal half is responsible for the 3'ncision and the C-terminal half is responsible for the 5'ncision. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_00203}.

The UvrABC repair system catalyzes the recognition androcessing of DNA lesions. A damage recognition complex composedf 2 UvrA and 2 UvrB subunits scans DNA for abnormalities. Uponinding of the UvrA(2)B(2) complex to a putative damaged site, theNA wraps around one UvrB monomer. DNA wrap is dependent on ATPinding by UvrB and probably causes local melting of the DNAelix, facilitating insertion of UvrB beta-hairpin between the DNAtrands. Then UvrB probes one DNA strand for the presence of aesion. If a lesion is found the UvrA subunits dissociate and thevrB-DNA preincision complex is formed. This complex isubsequently bound by UvrC and the second UvrB is released. If noesion is found, the DNA wraps around the other UvrB subunit thatill check the other stand for damage. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-ule:MF_00204}.
Molecular Function: F:ATP binding; F:DNA binding; F:excinuclease ABC activity; F:helicase activity

Organism: Methanosarcina mazei (strain ATCC BAA-159 / DSM 3647 / Goe1 / Go1
Protein Function: Component of the F(420)H(2) dehydrogenase (FPO complex)hich is part of the energy-conserving F(420)H(2):heterodisulfidexidoreductase system. The membrane-bound electron transfer systemf the complex plays an important role in the metabolism ofethylotrophic methanogens when the organisms grow on methanol orethylamines. Catalyzes the oxidation of methanophenazine toihydromethanophenazine. It shuttles electrons from F(420)H(2),ia FAD and iron-sulfur (Fe-S) centers, to methanophenazine (anlectron carrier in the membrane). It couples the redox reactiono proton translocation (for every two electrons transferred, twoydrogen ions are translocated across the cytoplasmic membrane),nd thus conserves the redox energy in a proton gradient. It alsoatalyzes the oxidation of F(420)H(2) with quinones such as 2,3-imethyl-1,4-naphthoquinone, 2-methyl-1,4-naphthoquinone andetramethyl-p-benzoquinone. Might have a dual function, acting asn electron input module when connected to the membrane integralpo complex, or as a soluble single subunit, being involved in theeoxydation of reduced ferredoxin in the cytoplasmPubMed:21306561). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10751389,CO:0000269|PubMed:21306561, ECO:0000269|Ref.1}.

Protein Function: Component of the F(420)H(2) dehydrogenase (FPO complex)hich is part of the energy-conserving F(420)H(2):heterodisulfidexidoreductase system. The membrane-bound electron transfer systemf the complex plays an important role in the metabolism ofethylotrophic methanogens when the organisms grow on methanol orethylamines. Catalyzes the oxidation of methanophenazine toihydromethanophenazine. It shuttles electrons from F(420)H(2),ia FAD and iron-sulfur (Fe-S) centers, to methanophenazine (anlectron carrier in the membrane). It couples the redox reactiono proton translocation (for every two electrons transferred, twoydrogen ions are translocated across the cytoplasmic membrane),nd thus conserves the redox energy in a proton gradient. It alsoatalyzes the oxidation of F(420)H(2) with quinones such as 2,3-imethyl-1,4-naphthoquinone, 2-methyl-1,4-naphthoquinone andetramethyl-p-benzoquinone. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10751389,CO:0000269|Ref.1}.

Protein Function: ATPase which is responsible for recognizing, binding,nfolding and translocation of substrate proteins into therchaeal 20S proteasome core particle. Thus, the C-termini of the proteasomal ATPaseunction like a 'key in a lock' to induce gate opening andherefore regulate proteolysis. Protein Function: ATPase which is responsible for recognizing, binding,nfolding and translocation of substrate proteins into therchaeal 20S proteasome core particle. Is essential for openinghe gate of the 20S proteasome via an interaction with its C-erminus, thereby allowing substrate entry and access to the sitef proteolysis. Thus, the C-termini of the proteasomal ATPaseunction like a 'key in a lock' to induce gate opening andherefore regulate proteolysis. Unfolding activity requires energyrom ATP hydrolysis, whereas ATP binding alone promotes ATPase-20Sroteasome association which triggers gate opening, and supportsranslocation of unfolded substrates. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-ule:MF_00553}.
Biological Process: P:proteasomal protein catabolic process; P:protein unfolding

Allows the formation of correctly charged Gln-tRNA(Gln)hrough the transamidation of misacylated Glu-tRNA(Gln) inrganisms which lack glutaminyl-tRNA synthetase. Ints presence, the cleavage activity of the RNA polymeraseruncates the RNA back to position +15 in a stepwise manner byeleasing mainly dinucleotides from the 3'-end of the nascent RNA.he truncated RNAs are able to continue elongation. Involved inranscriptional proofreading and fidelity. Protein Function: CRISPR (clustered regularly interspaced shortalindromic repeat), is an adaptive immune system that providesrotection against mobile genetic elements (viruses, transposablelements and conjugative plasmids). CRISPR clusters containequences complementary to antecedent mobile elements and targetnvading nucleic acids. CRISPR clusters are transcribed androcessed into CRISPR RNA (crRNA). Cas3 plus Cascade participaten CRISPR interference, the third stage of CRISPR immunity. Actss a ssDNA and ssRNA nuclease, with both endo- and 3' to 5'xonuclease activities, acting on substrates with free single-tranded 3' ends. Double-stranded nucleic acids are notubstrates. Activity is higher for DNA than RNA. Templates include-loops (a bubble-like structure formed when ssRNA replaces onetrand in a dsDNA, such as crRNA is thought to form with CRISPRarget DNA), circular ssDNA, 2',3'-cAMP and 2',3'-cGMP. Probablyenerates 3'-phosphate and 5'-hydroxyl ends. In the presence ofhe Cas3 helicase and ATP dsDNA templates are also degraded.ECO:0000269|PubMed:22009198}.

Involved in the regulation of the intracellular balanceetween NAD(H) and NADP(H), and is a key enzyme in theiosynthesis of NADP. Catalyzes the phosphorylation andephosphorylation of NAD and NADP, respectively. Although it showsonflicting dual activities and is able to supply NADP, it seemshat its physiological role is to prevent excess accumulation ofADP. Kinase can use ATP and other nucleoside triphosphates (UTP,TP, CTP, GTP) as well as inorganic polyphosphate (poly(P)) ashosphoryl donors, however poly(P) is not considered to be thehysiological phosphoryl donor. NAD is the preferred substrate forhe kinase, but NADH can also be used as phosphoryl acceptor.hosphatase can use NADP or NADPH as phosphoryl donor, but NADP ishe preferred substrate. Phosphatase also has an activity towardhe terminal phosphate group at C-2 of adenosine in 2'-AMP andoward the phosphate group at C-1 of fructose 1,6-bisphosphate,ut not toward inositol 1-phosphate.ECO:0000269|PubMed:16192277}.
Molecular Function: F:ATP binding; F:metal ion binding; F:NAD binding; F:NAD+ kinase activity; F:NADP phosphatase activity
Biological Process: P:lysine metabolic process; P:NAD metabolic process; P:NADP biosynthetic process; P:phosphatidylinositol phosphorylation

Protein Function: Hydro-lyase with broad substrate specificity for cis-nsaturated tricarboxylic acids. Catalyzes both the reversibleehydration of (R)-homocitrate ((R)-2-hydroxybutane-1,2,4-ricarboxylate) to produce cis-homoaconitate ((Z)-but-1-ene-1,2,4-ricarboxylate), and its hydration to homoisocitrate ((1R,2S)-1-ydroxybutane-1,2,4-tricarboxylate). Is also able to hydrate thenalogous longer chain substrates cis-homo(2)-aconitate, cis-omo(3)-aconitate, and even the non-physiological cis-homo(4)-conitate with similar efficiency. These reactions are part of theiosynthesis pathway of coenzyme B. Can also catalyze theydration of maleate to (R)-malate, and that of cis-aconitate. Canot catalyze the hydration of citraconate and the dehydration ofS)-homocitrate, citramalate, 2-isopropylmalate, 3-sopropylmalate, citrate or threo-DL-isocitrate.ECO:0000269|PubMed:18765671, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20170198}.

Component of the F(420)H(2) dehydrogenase (FPO complex)hich is part of the energy-conserving F(420)H(2):heterodisulfidexidoreductase system. The membrane-bound electron transfer systemf the complex plays an important role in the metabolism ofethylotrophic methanogens when the organisms grow on methanol orethylamines. Catalyzes the oxidation of methanophenazine toihydromethanophenazine. It shuttles electrons from F(420)H(2),ia FAD and iron-sulfur (Fe-S) centers, to methanophenazine (anlectron carrier in the membrane). It couples the redox reactiono proton translocation (for every two electrons transferred, twoydrogen ions are translocated across the cytoplasmic membrane),nd thus conserves the redox energy in a proton gradient (Byimilarity). {ECO:0000250}.

Protein Function: Component of the F(420)H(2) dehydrogenase (FPO complex)hich is part of the energy-conserving F(420)H(2):heterodisulfidexidoreductase system. The membrane-bound electron transfer systemf the complex plays an important role in the metabolism ofethylotrophic methanogens when the organisms grow on methanol orethylamines. Catalyzes the oxidation of methanophenazine toihydromethanophenazine. It shuttles electrons from F(420)H(2),ia FAD and iron-sulfur (Fe-S) centers, to methanophenazine (anlectron carrier in the membrane). It couples the redox reactiono proton translocation (for every two electrons transferred, twoydrogen ions are translocated across the cytoplasmic membrane),nd thus conserves the redox energy in a proton gradient. It alsoatalyzes the oxidation of F(420)H(2) with quinones such as 2,3-imethyl-1,4-naphthoquinone, 2-methyl-1,4-naphthoquinone andetramethyl-p-benzoquinone. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10751389,CO:0000269|Ref.1}.
Molecular Function: F:4 iron, 4 sulfur cluster binding; F:metal ion binding; F:Methanosarcina-phenazine hydrogenase activity
